revision.text:
In [[linguistics]], '''clitic doubling''', or '''pronominal reduplication''' is a phenomenon by which [[clitic]] [[pronoun]]s appear in [[verb]] phrases together with the full [[noun phrase]]s that they refer to (as opposed to the cases where such pronouns and full noun phrases are in [[complementary distribution]]).
Clitic doubling is found in many languages, including [[Albanian language|Albanian]], [[Aromanian language|Aromanian]], [[Macedonian language|Macedonian]], [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], [[Degema language|Degema]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Romanian language|Romanian]], [[Somali language|Somali]], [[Italian language|Italian]], and [[Spanish language|Spanish]].
The conditions on clitic doubling vary from language to language, generally depending on well-known properties of the objects along the [[Animacy#Animacy hierarchy and morphosyntactic alignment|animacy hierarchy]] (allowing, requiring, or forbidding clitic-doubling for different kinds of objects). In this regard, clitic doubling for objects can be viewed as a species of [[differential object marking]].
== Spanish == Spanish is one well-known example of a clitic-doubling language, having clitic doubling for both direct and indirect objects. Because standard Spanish grammatical structure does not draw a clear distinction between an indirect object and a direct object referring to a person or another animate entity (see [[Spanish prepositions#a|Spanish prepositions]]), it is common but not compulsory to use clitic doubling to clarify. Compare:
:''Conocí a Juan''. "I met Juan." (Direct object: ''a Juan'') :''Di un regalo a Juan''. "I gave a gift to Juan." (Direct object: ''un regalo''; indirect object: ''a Juan'')
In such constructions, the indirect object can be expressed both as a full noun phrase and as a clitic in order to note that the noun phrase beginning with ''a'' (to) should be understood as an indirect object:
:''Le di un regalo a mi madre.'' "I gave my mother a gift." :''A mis invitados siempre les ofrezco café.'' "I always offer coffee to my guests." :''No les des comida a los animales.'' "Do not give food to the animals."
The above, if literally translated into English, would be redundant:
{| class="wikitable" |''Le'' |''di'' |''un'' |''regalo'' |''a'' |''mi'' |''madre'' |- |To her |I gave |a |gift |to |my |mother |}
{| class="wikitable" |''A'' |''mis'' |''invitados'' |''siempre'' |''les'' |''ofrezco'' |''café'' |- |to |my |guests |always |to them |I offer |coffee |}
{| class="wikitable" |''No'' |''les'' |''des'' |''comida'' |''a'' |''los'' |''animales'' |- |not |to them |give |food |to |the |animals |}
This usage is highly preferred for many verbs, but for some verbs it is not compulsory, and it would also be valid to say: "''Siempre ofrezco café a mis invitados''", without clitic doubling.
Similarly, the direct object may also be doubled, with both the direct object pronoun and the full noun phrase, but this is not as common as indirect clitic doubling and is usually influenced by definiteness, animacy, and specificity.
:''(Lo) vi a tu papá en la tienda.'' "I saw your dad at the store." :''El otro día (la) conocí a su esposa.'' "The other day I met his wife."
One particular use is to clarify emphatic structures:
:''Ese regalo se lo di a él.'' "I gave '''him''' that gift."
==Italian== In [[Italian language|Italian]], clitic doubling is used as [[colloquial]] [[pleonasm]], although it is considered incorrect by some.<ref>[http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/faq/faq_risp.php?id=4096&ctg_id=93 Accademia della Crusca, ''A me mi: è una forma corretta?'']</ref>
Example: ''a me mi pare di sì'' ("I [personally, for what I am concerned] think so")
==Iloko== In [[Ilokano language|Iloko]], a [[Grammatical person|third person]] pronoun must co-occur with the full noun phrase to which it refers when 1) the noun phrase is the [[Agent (grammar)|agent]] of a [[transitive verb]] and a pronoun is the [[Patient (grammar)|patient]], or when 2) the noun phrase is the possessor and a pronoun is the thing possessed. The appropriate [[Ilokano grammar#Enclitic personal-pronoun sequences|fused personal pronoun]] is used and the number of its third person component must agree with the noun phrase.
Examples: Nakita ni Maria ni Juan. ''Maria saw Juan.''
Nakitana ni Juan. ''She saw Juan.''
BUT... Nakitanaka ni Maria. ''Maria saw you.'' NOT ''*Nakitaka ni Maria.'' {| class="wikitable" |colspan="5"|''Maria saw you.'' |- |Na-||kita||'''-naka'''||ni||Maria |- |Perf. ABIL||"see"||'''3s ERG + 2s ABS'''||ART||PROPER NOUN |- |colspan="2"|saw||she=you||colspan="2"|Maria |} ''NOT:'' *Nakitaak ni Maria. {| class="wikitable" |colspan="8"|''Maria and John saw (the two of) us.'' |- |Na-||kita||'''-data'''||da||Maria||ken||ni||Juan |- |Perf. ABIL||"see"||'''3p ERG + 1d ABS'''||ART||PROPER NOUN||CONJ||ART||PROPER NOUN |- |colspan="2"|saw||they=(two of) us||colspan="5"|Maria and John |} ''NOT:'' *Nakitaak da Maria ken ni Juan. {| class="wikitable" |colspan="5"|''You are the Rizals' child.'' |- |Anak||'''-daka'''||dagiti||ag-||Rizal |- |"child"||'''3p ERG + 2s ABS'''||ART||KINSHIP||PROPER NOUN |- ||child||their=you||colspan="3"|the Rizal's |} ''NOT:'' *Anakka dagiti Rizal.
== Lombard == In [[Lombard language|Lombard]], clitics are widely used with both nouns and pronouns.
Te gh'el diset ti a la Rina che l'è staa luu? Will you tell OR Would you mind telling Rina it was him [who did it]?
{| class="wikitable" |''Te'' |''gh''' |''el'' |''diset'' |''ti'' |''a la Rina'' |''che'' |''l''' |''è'' |''staa'' |''luu?'' |- |You |to her |it |(you) tell |you |to Rina |that |it |has |been |he? | |}
== Venetian == In [[Venetian language|Venetian]], clitics usually double the second singular person subject and third singular and plural subject.
The above, if literally translated into English, would be redundant:
{| class="wikitable" |''I'' |''mii'' |''i'' |''vien'' |''doman'' |- |The (parents) |mine |they |come |tomorrow |} 'My parents come tomorrow'
{| class="wikitable" |''Marco'' |''el'' |''Vien'' |''doman'' |- |Marco |he |comes |tomorrow |} 'Marco comes tomorrow'
{| class="wikitable" |''Ti'' |''te/ti/tu'' |''vien'' |''doman'' |- |You |you |come |tomorrow |} 'You come tomorrow'
Interrogative subjects clitics double also other subjects. They attach to the verb:
{| class="wikitable" |''Cantè-o'' |''anca'' |''voaltri/e ?'' |- |Sing-you |also |you (pl.m/f) |} 'Do you (pl.) sing as well?'
Accusative clitics double first and second singular/plural direct object {| class="wikitable" |''Te'' |''go'' |''visto'' |''ti'' |- |you |(I) have |seen |you |}
In some varieties of the language, also dative clitics may double and indirect object, even of third person: {| class="wikitable" |''Marco'' |''el'' |''ghe'' |''ga'' |''dà'' |''un libro'' |''a Toni'' |- |Mark |he |to him |has |given |a book |to Tony |}
==Macedonian and Bulgarian== In the standard [[Macedonian language]], clitic doubling is obligatory with [[definiteness|definite]] [[direct object|direct]] and [[indirect object]]s, which contrasts with standard Bulgarian where clitic doubling is optional. Non-standard dialects of Macedonian and Bulgarian have differing rules regarding clitic doubling.{{ref|friedman1994}}
== Degema == Clitic doubling occurs in [[Degema language|Degema]], as it does in Romance and Slavic languages. However, clitic doubling in Degema is not associated with the presence of a preposition as in Romance languages like Spanish nor is it associated with topicality or specificity as in Slavic languages like Bulgarian. Rather, what make clitic doubling in Degema possible are syntactic (movement and anaphoricity) and discourse (emphasis and/or familiarity) factors (Kari 2003){{ref|kari2003}} Consider (1) below:
(1) Eni mo=sire elephant cl=run 'An elephant is running'
In (1) the subject noun phrase (NP) 'Eni' is doubled by the clitic 'mo='. The clitic agrees in person, number and case with the doubled subject NP.
Example (2) shows that specific and non-specific subjects in Degema can be doubled by a clitic:
(2) Eni mo=rere (non-specific) elephant cl=walk 'An elephant is walking'
Eni mee mo=rere (specific) elephant my cl=walk 'My elephant is walking'
Example (3) shows that both topicalized and non-topicalized NPs in Degema can be doubled by a clitic:
(3) Okper o=kun esen (non-topicalized) Otter cl=catch.factative fish 'An Otter caught a fish'
Okper nu o=kun esen (topicalized) Otter Focus marker cl=catch.factative fish 'It was an Otter that caught a fish'
In Degema, the preposition does not feature in clitic doubling constructions in particular and in cliticization in general. Although there are object NPs such as indirect object NPs that can cooccur with a preposition, there are no corresponding object clitics to double them, unlike subject NPs.
Kari (2003: 135f) adds that "syntactic factors are stronger than discourse factors in the licensing of clitic doubling in Degema. Discourse factors only ensure the expression or suppression of the doubled NP after syntactic operations have taken place".
==See also== *[[Resumptive pronoun]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== # {{note|friedman1994}} Friedman, V. (1994) "Variation and Grammaticalization in the Development of Balkanisms" in ''CLS 30 Papers from the 30th Regional Meeting of the Chicago Linguistic Society'', Volume 2. (Chicago: Chicago Linguistic Society) # {{note|kari2003}} Kari, Ethelbert Emmanuel. 2003. ''Clitics in Degema: A meeting point of phonology, morphology, and syntax''. Tokyo: Research Institute for Languages and Cultures of Asia and Africa (ILCAA). {{ISBN|4-87297-850-1}}.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Clitic Doubling}} [[Category:Grammar]] [[Category:Reduplication]]

{{Multiple issues| {{notability|date=December 2016}} {{Orphan|date=December 2016}} }}
'''Critical data studies''' is the systematic study of data and its criticisms. The field was named by scholars [[Craig Dalton]] and [[Jim Thatcher]].<ref name=":1">{{cite web|last1=Dalton|first1=Craig|last2=Thatcher|first2=Jim|title=What does a Critical Data Studies look like and why do we care?|url=http://societyandspace.org/2014/05/12/what-does-a-critical-data-studies-look-like-and-why-do-we-care-craig-dalton-and-jim-thatcher/#|website=Society + Space|date=12 May 2014|accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref> Prior to its naming, significant interest in critical data studies was generated by [[danah boyd]] and [[Kate Crawford]], who posed a set of research questions for the critical study of [[big data]] and its impacts on society and culture.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=boyd|first1=danah|last2=Crawford|first2=Kate|title=Critical questions for Big Data|journal=Information, Communication & Society|date=10 May 2012|volume=15|issue=5|pages=662–679|doi=10.1080/1369118X.2012.678878}}</ref> As its name implies, critical data studies draws heavily on the influence of [[critical theory]] which it applies to the study of [[data]]. Subsequently, others have worked to further solidify a field called critical data studies. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Iliadis|first=Andrew|last2=Russo|first2=Federica|date=2016-10-17|title=Critical data studies: An introduction|journal=Big Data & Society|language=en|volume=3|issue=2|pages=205395171667423|doi=10.1177/2053951716674238}}</ref> Some of the other key scholars in this discipline include [[Rob Kitchin]] and [[Tracey P. Lauriault]].<ref>Kitchin, Rob, and Tracey P. Lauriault, 2014</ref><ref name=":2">Kitchin, Rob, 2014</ref> Scholars have attempted to make sense of data through different theoretical frameworks, some of which include analyzing data technically, ethically, politically/economically, temporally/spatially, and philosophically.<ref name=":2" /> Some of the key academic journals related to critical data studies include the ''[[Journal of Big Data]]'' and ''[[Big Data and Society]]''.
==Motivation==
In their article in which they coin the term 'critical data studies,' Dalton and Thatcher also provide several justifications as to why data studies is a discipline worthy of a critical approach.<ref>Dalton, Craig, and Jim Thatcher, 2014.</ref> Firstly, 'big data' is an important aspect of twenty-first century society, and the analysis of 'big data' allows for a deeper understanding of what is happening and for what reasons.<ref name=":1" /> Furthermore, big data as a technological tool and the information that it yields are not neutral, according to Dalton and Thatcher, making it worthy of critical analysis in order to identify and address its biases. Building off this idea, another justification for a critical approach is that the relationship between big data and society is an important one, and therefore worthy of study.<ref name=":1" /> Dalton and Thatcher stress how the relationship is not an example of [[technological determinism]], but rather how big data can shape the lives of individuals. Big data technology can cause significant changes in society's structure and in the everyday lives of people,<ref name=":1" /> and being a product of society, big data technology is worthy of sociological investigation.<ref name=":1" /> Moreover, data sets are almost never completely raw, that is to say without any influences. Rather, data are shaped by the vision or goals of a research team, and during the data collection process, certain things are quantified, stored, sorted and even discarded by the research team.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Michael|first=Mike|last2=Lupton|first2=Deborah|date=2015-10-13|title=Toward a manifesto for the 'public understanding of big data'|journal=Public Understanding of Science|language=en|volume=25|issue=1|pages=104–116|doi=10.1177/0963662515609005|pmid=26468128|url=http://www.canberra.edu.au/researchrepository/items/0649f4e2-e43e-4e60-b8f7-a5f12801ebcd/1/}}</ref> A critical approach is thus necessary in order to understand and reveal the intent behind the information being presented. Moreover, data alone cannot speak for itself; in order to possess any concrete meaning, data must be accompanied by theoretical insight or alternative quantitative or qualitative research measures.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bar-Yam|first=Yaneer|date=2016-11-01|title=From big data to important information|journal=Complexity|language=en|volume=21|issue=S2|pages=73–98|doi=10.1002/cplx.21785|issn=1099-0526|arxiv=1604.00976|bibcode=2016Cmplx..21S..73B}}</ref> Dalton and Thatcher argue that if one were to only think of data in terms of its exploitative power, there is no possibility of using data for revolutionary, liberatory purposes.<ref name=":1" /> Finally, Dalton and Thatcher propose that a critical approach in studying data allows for 'big data' to be combined with older, 'small data,' and thus create more thorough research, opening up more opportunities, questions and topics to be explored.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Abreu|first1=Amelia|last2=Acker|first2=Amelia|title=Context and collection: A research agenda for small data|journal=IConference 2013 Proceedings|date=2013|pages=549–554|doi=10.9776/13275|url=https://www.ideals.illinois.edu/handle/2142/39750|accessdate=17 January 2018|doi-broken-date=2018-11-04}}</ref>
==Issues and concerns for critical data scholars==
The use of data in modern society brings about new ways of understanding and measuring the world, but also brings with it certain concerns or issues.<ref name=":2" /> Data scholars attempt to bring some of these issues to light in their quest to be critical of data. Rob Kitchin identifies both technical and organizational issues of data, as well as some normative and ethical questions.<ref name=":2" /> Technical and organization issues concerning data range from the scope of datasets, access to the data, the quality of the data, the integration of the data, the application of analytics and ecological fallacies, as well as the skills and organizational capabilities of the research team.<ref name=":2" /> Some of the normative and ethical concerns addressed by Kitchin include surveillance through one's data ([[dataveillance]]<ref name=":0" />), the privacy of one's data, the ownership of one's data, the security of one's data, anticipatory or corporate governance, and profiling individuals by their data.<ref name=":2" /> All of these concerns must be taken into account by scholars of data in their objective to be critical.
Following in the tradition of critical urban studies,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Brenner | first1 = Neil| title = What is critical urban theory? | journal = City | volume = 13| issue = 2–3| pages = 198–207| doi = 10.1080/13604810902996466 | date = 2009 | ref = harv }}</ref> other scholars have raised similar concerns around data and digital information technologies in the urban context.<ref>{{cite web | last = Joe Shaw and Mark Graham | title = Our Digital Rights to the City | url = http://meatspacepress.org/ | website = meatspacepress.org | publisher = Meatspace Press | date = 15 February 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Crawford|first=Kate|last2=Finn|first2=Megan|date=2015-08-01|title=The limits of crisis data: analytical and ethical challenges of using social and mobile data to understand disasters|journal=GeoJournal|language=en|volume=80|issue=4|pages=491–502|doi=10.1007/s10708-014-9597-z|issn=0343-2521}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pickren|first=Graham|date=2016-10-12|title=The global assemblage of digital flow|journal=Progress in Human Geography|volume=42|issue=2|pages=225–243|language=en|doi=10.1177/0309132516673241}}</ref> For example, Joe Shaw and Mark Graham have examined these in light of [[Henri Lefebvre]]'s '[[right to the city]]'.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Shaw|first1=Joe|last2=Graham|first2=Mark|date=February 2017|title=An Informational Right to the City? Code, Content, Control, and the Urbanization of Information|journal=[[Antipode (journal)|Antipode]]|volume=49|issue=4|pages=907|doi=10.1111/anti.12312|ref=harv}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|24em}}
==Sources== * Dalton, Craig, and Jim Thatcher. "What does a critical data studies look like, and why do we care? Seven points for a critical approach to ‘big data’." ''Society and Space open site'' (2014). Retrieved October 23, 2016. * Elkins, James R. "The Critical Thinking Movement: Alternating Currents in One Teacher's Thinking". ''myweb.wvnet.edu''(1999). Retrieved 29 November 2016. * Kitchin, Rob. ''The data revolution: Big data, open data, data infrastructures and their consequences.'' Sage, 2014. Retrieved October 23, 2016. * Kitchin, Rob, and Tracey P. Lauriault. "Towards critical data studies: Charting and unpacking data assemblages and their work." (2014). Retrieved October 23, 2016.

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Statua di Amore e Psiche.jpg|thumb|''Cupid and Psyche'', Roman marble sculpture after a [[Hellenistic]] original, h. 1.25m ([[Capitoline Museums]])]] The marble '''''[[Cupid and Psyche]]''''' conserved in the [[Capitoline Museums]],<ref>Musei Capitolini, inv. MC0408.</ref> [[Rome]], is a 1st or 2nd century CE<!--this article uses the BCE/CE convention--> Roman copy of a late [[Hellenistic]] original.<ref>Wolfgang Helbig, ''et al.'' ''Führer durch die öffentichen Sammlungen klassischer Altertümer in Rom'', 1963-72, vol. ii:238f.</ref> It was given to the nascent Capitoline Museums by [[Pope Benedict XIV]] in 1749, shortly after its discovery. Its graceful balance and sentimental appearance made it a favourite among the [[Neoclassicism|neoclassical]] generations of artists and visitors, and it was copied in many materials from bronze to [[biscuit porcelain]].<ref>Various copies in a range of materials are noted by Francis Haskell and Nicholas Penny, ''Taste and the Antique: the lure of classical sculpture 1500-1900'' 1981: cat. no. 26, pp189-91.</ref> [[Antonio Canova]] consciously set out to outdo the Antique original with his own ''Cupid and Psyche'' of 1808 (''illustration, below left'')
The sculpture was discovered in the garden of the ''vigna'' of the canonico Panicale on the [[Aventine Hill]] in February 1749.<ref>(Giovanni Pietro Lucatelli), ''Museo Capitolino, o sia descrizione delle statue'', Rome, 1750:30, described as "a graceful group of a man and woman tenderly embracing", noted by Haskell and Penny 1981; the description and discovery in the ''vigna del canonico Panicale'' are repeated in Filippo Titi, ''Descrizione delle pitture, sculture e architetture esposte al pubblico in Roma'', Rome, 1763:vol. II:22, and every guidebook since.</ref>
The sculpture quite eclipsed a Roman marble of a winged Cupid and Psyche that had been discovered in the 17th century and removed to the [[Uffizi|Medici collection]] in [[Florence]]. The Capitoline ''Cupid and Psyche'' was among the cream of the Roman collections sequestered by the French under the terms of the [[treaty of Tolentino]] (1797) and transferred to [[Paris]] amid grand theatrics. It was returned to Rome after the fall of Napoleon.
Not all viewers were satisfied by its mediocre execution, and [[Francis Haskell]] and [[Nicholas Penny]] noted that Jean-Baptiste de Saint-Victor<ref>Saint-Victor, ''Musée des Antiques. Dessiné et gravé par [[Pierre Bouillon|P. Bouillon]] peintre, avec des notices explicatives'', Paris, 1818:vol. I.</ref> thought it was a reflection of some earlier, better work, and that, earlier, Joseph-Jerome Le Français de Lalande hoped in print<ref>Lalande, ''Voyage d'un François en Italie'', Paris, 1769, reflecting his voyage of 1765-66; an expanded edition was issued in 1787-88; noted by Haskell and Penny.</ref> that it might inspire some modern sculptor to come up with a superior work on the same subject. Antonio Canova took up the challenge quite consciously, in his ''Cupid and Psyche'' of 1808. [[File:Canova-Cupd and Psyche 300degree view.jpg|thumb|upright|left|''Cupid and Psyche'' by [[Antonio Canova]], 1808 ([[Hermitage Museum]], St Petersburg)]] Another version of the ''Cupid and Psyche'' was discovered by conte [[Giuseppe Fede]] in his early excavations at [[Hadrian's Villa]], [[Tivoli, Italy|Tivoli]]. It has disappeared now, but it was drawn, in its completed and restored condition, by [[Pompeo Batoni]], who was assembling a "paper museum"<ref>Compare the "paper museum" compiled by [[Cassiano dal Pozzo]].</ref> of antiquities in 1727-30 for the English antiquary Richard Topham.<ref>The Topham Batoni drawing, with the rest of his collection, has passed to the library of [[Eton College]]; the drawing is illustrated in Haskell and Penny 1981:93, fig. 52</ref> As it was restored, Cupid turns his head away coyly.
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2013}} [[California]] is the most populated [[U.S. state]], with an estimated population of 39.497 million as of 2017.{{cite web|url=http://worldpopulationreview.com/states/california-population/|title=California Population 2017 (Demographics, Maps, Graphs)|website=Worldpopulationreview.com|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} It has people from a wide variety of [[ethnic]], [[Race (classification of human beings)|racial]], national, and [[religious]] backgrounds. ==Population== {{US Census population |1850= 92597 |1860= 379994 |1870= 560247 |1880= 864694 |1890= 1213398 |1900= 1485053 |1910= 2377549 |1920= 3426861 |1930= 5677251 |1940= 6907387 |1950= 10586223 |1960= 15717204 |1970= 19953134 |1980= 23667902 |1990= 29760021 |2000= 33871648 |2010= 37253956 |2020 (projection)= 43.5 million |footnote= Sources: 1910-2010{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/2010census/data/apportionment-pop-text.php|title=Resident Population Data - 2010 Census|website=Census.gov|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} }} California is the most populated sub-national entity in North America. If it were an independent country, California would rank 34th in population in the world. It has a larger population than either [[Canada]] or [[Australia]].{{cite news |title=California's population ahead of Canada, behind Poland at 37.8 million |author=Don Thompson |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20071220/news_1n20calpop.html |newspaper=San Diego Union Tribune |date=20 December 2007 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} Its population is one third larger than that of the next largest state, [[Texas]].{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/statab/ranks/rank01.html|title=Statistical Abstract of the United States|website=Census.gov|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} California surpassed [[New York (state)|New York]] to become the most populous state in 1962.{{Cite web |title = Governor Edmund G. "Pat" Brown of California |publisher = California State Library |date = November 28, 2005 |url = http://www.californiagovernors.ca.gov/h/biography/governor_32.html |accessdate = January 29, 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100114163734/http://californiagovernors.ca.gov/h/biography/governor_32.html |archivedate = January 14, 2010 |df = mdy-all }} However, according to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', California's population growth has slowed dramatically in the 21st century.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/04/california-population-growth.html|title=California's population growth is slowing dramatically in the 21st century, study finds|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=2012-04-24|accessdate=2013-06-06}} In 2010, the state's five most populous counties were [[Los Angeles County]], [[San Diego County]], [[Orange County, California|Orange County]], [[Riverside County]], and [[San Bernardino County]], with Riverside County having the largest percentage increase in population.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.csac.counties.org/index.php/2010/12/california-county-population-shows-little-growth/ |title=California County Population Shows Little Growt |author=Erin Treadwell |date=9 December 2010 |website=csas.counties.org |publisher=California State Association of Counties |accessdate=6 June 2013}} The [[List of California urban areas|largest metro areas in California]], as of 2010, are [[Los Angeles metropolitan area|Los Angeles]], [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]]-[[Oakland, California|Oakland]]-[[San Jose, California|San Jose]], [[San Diego Metro|San Diego]], [[Inland Empire (California)|Riverside-San Bernardino]], and [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]].{{cite web |url=https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2012/03/27/2012-6903/qualifying-urban-areas-for-the-2010-census |title=Qualifying Urban Areas for the 2010 Census |author= |date=27 March 2012 |website=Federal Register |publisher=United States Government |accessdate=13 November 2013}} From 2006 until 2016, the state lost a net population of about 1 million people from domestic immigration;{{cite news |last=Riquier |first=Andrea |date=6 May 2018 |title=With no letup in home prices, the California exodus surges |url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/with-no-letup-in-home-prices-the-california-exodus-surges-2018-05-03 |work=MarketWatch |location=New York, New York |access-date=6 May 2018 }}
{{cite report |author=Brian Uhler |author2=Justin Garosi |date=21 February 2018 |title=California Losing Residents Via Domestic Migration |url=http://lao.ca.gov/LAOEconTax/Article/Detail/265 |publisher=State of California |access-date=6 May 2018 }} the plurality of whom moved to [[Texas]], yet the population of the state continued to grow due to migration from overseas.{{cite news |last=Reese |first=Phillip |date= |title=Roughly 5 million people left California in the last decade. See where they went. |url=http://www.sacbee.com/site-services/databases/article32679753.html |work= Sacramento Bee |access-date=6 May 2018 }} As of 2006, California had an estimated population of 37,172,015, more than 12 percent of the U.S. population. This includes a natural increase since the last census of 1,557,112 people ( i.e. 2,781,539 births minus 1,224,427 deaths) and an increase due to net migration of 751,419 people. Immigration resulted in a net increase of 1,415,879 people, and migration from within the U.S. resulted in a net decrease of 564,100 people. California is the 13th fastest-growing state. As of 2008, the total fertility rate was 2.15.{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nvsr/nvsr59/nvsr59_01.pdf|title=Cdc.gov|website=Cdc.gov|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} The most recent census reports the population of California as 39,144,818. The [[center of population]] of [[California]] is located at {{Coord|35.463595|N|119.325359|W|display=inline}} in [[Kern County, California|Kern County]], near the town of [[Shafter, California|Shafter]].[http://www2.census.gov/geo/docs/reference/cenpop2010/CenPop2010_Mean_ST.txt Population and Population Centers by State: 2010]. United States Census Bureau. Retrieved February 5, 2017. No single ethnic group forms a majority of California's population, making the state a [[minority-majority state]]. Hispanics (of any race) are the largest single ethnic group in the state.{{Cite web| title = California QuickFacts from the US Census Bureau| publisher = United States Census Bureau| url = https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/table/RHI705210/06| accessdate = July 16, 2016}} [[Spanish language|Spanish]] is the state's second most widely spoken language. Areas with especially large Spanish speaking populations include the [[Los Angeles metropolitan area]], the [[US-Mexico border|California-Mexico border]] counties of [[San Diego County|San Diego]] and [[Imperial County, California|Imperial]], and the [[San Joaquin Valley]]. Nearly 43% of Californian residents speak a language other than English at home, a proportion far higher than any other state.{{cite web|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2008-09-23/news/17160872_1_language-gap-limited-english-speakers-immigrants|title=43% in state speak other than English at home|website=Articles.sfgate.com|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} California is home to almost 25% of the country's undocumented population, making up 6% of California's residents overall. Two-thirds of California's undocumented population have lived in the state for more than 10 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.ppic.org/main/publication_show.asp?i=818|title=Undocumented Immigrants in California - Public Policy Institute of California|website=Ppic.org|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} About 26% of California's [[State school|public school]] students in the 2011–12 school year identified themselves as white (non-Hispanic), and 52% of the state's students identified themselves as Hispanic or Latino. The following ethnic groups that made up the statewide public school student body were Asians (11%), African Americans (7%), Native Americans (0.7%), and Pacific Islanders (0.6%). Students of mixed race made up about 2% of the public schools. Hispanics made up the majority of the state's public schools since 2010. [[Los Angeles Unified School District]], the largest school district in California and second largest in the nation, is 73% Hispanic, 10% African American, 9% non-Hispanic Caucasian, 6% Asian, 0.5% Native American, and 0.4% Pacific Islander.{{cite web|publisher=California Department of Education|url=http://dq.cde.ca.gov/dataquest/Enrollment/EthnicEnr.aspx?cYear=2011-12&cGender=B&cType=ALL&cChoice=StEnrEth2|title=Enrollment by Ethnicity for 2011–12: Statewide Enrollment by Ethnicity (with county data) |accessdate=April 21, 2012}} In 2011, there was an estimated 2.6 million [[Illegal immigration to the United States|undocumented immigrants]] residing in California. Full parameter set in horizontal format {{cite report |first=Laura E. |last=Hill |first2=Hans P |last2=Johnson |first3=David |last3=Ezekiel |first4=Joseph M. |last4= Hayes |date= July 2011 |title= Unauthorized Immigrants in California |url=http://www.ppic.org/content/pubs/report/R_711LHR.pdf |publisher=Public Policy Institute of California |contribution=Silicon Valley Community Foundation |page= |docket= |access-date=26 June 2018 |quote= }} ==National origin== [[File:California population map.png|thumb|right|280px|Population density]] {{Pie chart | caption= Racial/Ethnic Makeup of California treating Hispanics as a Separate Category (2017) {{cite web|url=https://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/ACS/17_1YR/B03002/0400000US06|title=B03002 HISPANIC OR LATINO ORIGIN BY RACE - California - 2017 American Community Survey 1-Year Estimates|date=July 1, 2017 |publisher=[[U.S. Census Bureau]] |access-date=October 11, 2018}} | label1 = White Non-Hispanic | value1 = 37.20| color2=#36A | label2 = Black Non-Hispanic | value2 = 5.47 | color1=#6A5 | label3 = Native American Non-Hispanic | value3 = 0.37 | color3=#FF33AC | label4 = Asian Non-Hispanic | value4 = 14.37 | color4=#1A9 | label5 = Pacific Islander Non-Hispanic | value5 = 0.35| color5=#E17720 | label6 = Other Non-Hispanic | value6 = 0.27 | color6=#F0FF00 | label7 = Two or more races Non-Hispanic | value7 = 3.05 | color7=#64ECDF | label8 = Hispanic Any Race | value8 = 39.15 | color8=#9400D3 | footnotes = 0.27% of Hispanics identify as Black }} [[File:052607-008-3StP-facing-SMP.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Pedestrians walking on the [[Third Street Promenade]] in Santa Monica.]] According to 2015 US Census Bureau estimates, California's population was 72.9% [[White American|White]], 6.5% Black or [[African American]], 14.7% [[Asian American|Asian]], 1.7% [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]], 0.5% [[Pacific Islander]] and 3.8% from [[Multiracial American|two or more races]]. By ethnicity, 38.8% of the total population is [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic-Latino]] (of any race) and 61.4% Non-Hispanic (of any race). Hispanics are the largest ethnic group in California.{{Cite web | title = California QuickFacts from the US Census Bureau | publisher = United States Census Bureau | url = https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/table/RHI705210/06 | accessdate = July 16, 2016}} In 2015, California had the largest [[Majority-minority state|minority]] population in the United States. [[Non-Hispanic whites]] decreased from about 76.3 - 78% of the state's population in 1970{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/population/www/documentation/twps0056/tab19.xls|title=Historical Census Statistics on Population Totals By Race, California|website=Census.gov|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} to 38.0% in 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/table/PST045215/06|title=Census.gov|website=Census.gov|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} While the population of minorities accounts for 100.7 million of 300 million U.S. residents, 20% of the national total live in California.{{Cite web | title = California - ACS Demographic and Housing Estimates: 2006-2008 | work = American Fact Finder | publisher = US Census Bureau | url = http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/ADPTable?_bm=y&-geo_id=04000US06&-qr_name=ACS_2008_3YR_G00_DP3YR5&-ds_name=ACS_2008_3YR_G00_&-_lang=en&-_sse=on | accessdate = December 26, 2009}}{{Cite web | title = United States - ACS Demographic and Housing Estimates: 2006-2008 | work = American Fact Finder | publisher = US Census Bureau | url = http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/ADPTable?_bm=y&-geo_id=01000US&-qr_name=ACS_2008_3YR_G00_DP3YR5&-ds_name=ACS_2008_3YR_G00_&-_lang=en&-redoLog=false&-_sse=on | accessdate = December 26, 2009}} California has the highest number, and second highest percentage, of [[Asian American]]s by state. Only [[Hawaii]] has a higher Asian American percentage than California. While [[New Mexico]] and [[Texas]] have higher percentages of Hispanics, California has the highest total number of Hispanics of any U.S. state. Hispanics are the largest single ethnic group in the state.{{Cite web| title = California QuickFacts from the US Census Bureau - Race and Hispanic Origin| publisher = United States Census Bureau| url = https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/table/RHI705210/35,15,48,06| accessdate = July 16, 2016}} The largest named ancestries in California are [[Mexican American|Mexican]] (25%), [[German American|German]] (9%), [[Irish Americans|Irish]] (7.7%), [[English Americans|English]] (7.4%) and Italian (5.8%); there are 65 other ethnicities with sizable populations in California including [[Albanians]], [[Australians]], [[Canadians]], [[Haitians]], and [[Somali people|Somalis]] as examples. Both Los Angeles and San Francisco have large numbers of residents with [[English people|English]], [[French people|French]], [[Italian people|Italian]], [[German Americans|German]], [[Russian people|Russian]] and [[Scandinavia]]n ancestry.{{Citation needed|date=July 2016}} California has the largest population of White Americans in the U.S., totaling 21,453,934 residents as of the 2010 census. The state has the fifth largest population of African Americans in the U.S., an estimated 2,299,072 residents. California's Asian population is estimated at 4.9 million, approximately one-third of the nation's estimated 15 million Asian Americans. California's Native American population of 285,512 is the third-largest of any state, behind Arizona and Oklahoma.{{Cite web| last = US Census Bureau| title = 2012-2016 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates| accessdate = 2018-02-07| date = 2016}} Other estimates place the Native American population of California at one million. {{Citation needed|date=June 2008}} {{US Demographics|state=California}} Since the 2000 [[United States Census|U.S. Census]], California has been known as the second state in US history (after Hawaii since its statehood in 1959) to have a non-white majority, and since 2014, the first state to have a Latino plurality surpass other racial/ethnic groups. The media discussed the possibility of Latinos becoming a majority in the 21st century,{{cite web|url=http://www.sacbee.com/news/local/article25940218.html|title=Census: Hispanics overtake whites to become California’s largest ethnic group|first1=Phillip|last1=Reese|first2=Stephen|last2=Magagnini|date=June 30, 2015|website=Sacbee.com|accessdate=October 7, 2017|via=Sacramento Bee}} for the first time since statehood (1850) when massive immigration of Anglo-Americans during the [[California Gold Rush]] of 1848-49 reduced Spanish speakers to 20 percent of the population. California has the largest population of [[European Americans]] of any state. For example, in 2000 California had more [[Bulgarian Americans]], [[Romanian Americans]] and [[Hungarian Americans]] than any other U.S. state. Los Angeles and San Francisco have large [[Russian American]] or [[Russia]]n populations, as well [[Ukrainian American]]s; and a long history of [[English American|English]], [[Irish American|Irish]], [[Italian Americans|Italian]], [[German Americans|German]], and [[Polish Americans|Polish]] communities established by immigrants in the late 19th century. There are also many [[English Americans]], [[Irish Americans]], and [[French American]]s whose ancestors were the original 49ers, also known as the [[California Gold Rush]] immigrants. There are also immigrant communities from the former [[Yugoslavia]] such as [[Bosnian American|Bosnians]], [[Croatian American|Croatians]], and [[Serbian American|Serbians]].{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} California has over one million residents each with [[Spanish American|Spanish]] or [[Portuguese American|Portuguese]] ancestry {{citation needed|date=May 2016}}, with communities along coastal parts of the state such as San Diego, [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]], [[Camarillo, California|Camarillo]], [[Santa Clara Valley]] (including [[Cupertino, California|Cupertino]], [[Gilroy, California|Gilroy]] and [[San Jose, California|San Jose]]), [[Salinas Valley]], [[Santa Maria Valley]], and [[San Joaquin Valley]]. A small wave of [[Danish people|Danish]], [[Dutch people|Dutch]] and [[Swedish people|Swedish]] immigrants founded towns like [[Lathrop, California|Lathrop]] near Stockton, [[Artesia, California|Artesia]] near Los Angeles, [[Kingsburg, California|Kingsburg]] south of Fresno, [[Solvang, California|Solvang]] north of Santa Barbara in the late 1800s and the private community of [[Sveadal]] located 15 miles south of [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] and populated entirely by members of the [[Swedish American]] Patriotic League.{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515093203/http://www.sveadal.org/SAPL/Welcome.html|title=the Swedish American Patriotic league|date=May 15, 2009|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=November 7, 2017}} Small colonies of early 19th century [[Russia]]n settlement under the [[Russian American Company]] are in [[Fort Ross, California|Fort Ross]],{{cite web|url=http://www.fortross.org/|title=Fort Ross, California|website=Fortross.org|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} [[Calistoga, California|Calistoga]] and the [[Russian River (California)|Russian River]] Valley in [[Sonoma County, California|Sonoma]] and [[Napa County, California|Napa]] counties. Small [[Amish]]/[[Mennonite]] colonies exist in an area bordered by the towns Oakdale, Riverbank and Ripon near [[Modesto, California|Modesto]] and in Reedley, Sanger and Orange Cove near Fresno in the [[San Joaquin Valley]]; and in the outer [[Salinas Valley]].{{cite web|url=http://amishamerica.com/california-amish-community/|title=A California Amish Community|website=amishamerica.com|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} The state also has over 2000 [[Circassians|Circassian Americans]] with a little community in [[Anaheim]]. [[Hispanics and Latinos in California|Latino]]s, mainly [[Mexican American]]s, form major portions of the population of Southern California, especially in [[Los Angeles]], as well as the San Joaquin Valley. The city of Los Angeles is often said to be the largest Mexican community in the United States. Census records kept track of the growth since 1850, but Mexicans and Mexican-Americans have lived in California since Spanish Colonial times. However, the number and percentage population of Latinos living in California increased rapidly in the late 20th century. The result is that, today, Latinos are the largest ethnic group in [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]], at over 40 percent of the county's population. Latinos are predominantly concentrated in the older eastern and southern suburbs surrounding downtown Los Angeles and northern Long Beach, the southern/eastern [[San Fernando Valley]], and the [[San Gabriel Valley|San Gabriel]]/[[Pomona Valley]]s. They also comprise sizable communities in [[Arvin, California|Arvin]], Bakersfield, [[Delano, California|Delano]], [[El Monte, California|El Monte]], [[Fontana, California|Fontana]], Fresno, [[Indio, California|Indio]], [[La Puente, California|La Puente]], [[Ontario, California|Ontario]], [[Oxnard, California|Oxnard]], Riverside, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Diego, San José, Santa Barbara, [[Santa Maria, California|Santa Maria]], [[Stockton, California|Stockton]], [[Vallejo, California|Vallejo]] and [[Yuba City, California|Yuba City]]. In [[Santa Ana, California|Santa Ana]] in Orange County, Latinos comprise 75 percent of the population. Nearby [[Anaheim, California|Anaheim]] is over half Latino, and Orange County's population is 30-35 percent Latino. The [[Imperial Valley (California)|Imperial Valley]] on the U.S.-Mexican border is about 70–75% Latino; communities with many Latinos can also be found in [[Riverside County, California|Riverside County]], especially at its eastern end, and the [[Coachella Valley]]. The [[California Central Valley|Central Valley]] has many Mexican American migrant farm workers. Latinos are the majority in 14 counties: [[Colusa County, California|Colusa]], [[Fresno County, California|Fresno]], [[Glenn County, California|Glenn]], [[Imperial County, California|Imperial]], [[Kern County, California|Kern]], [[Kings County, California|Kings]], [[Madera County, California|Madera]], [[Merced County, California|Merced]], [[Monterey County, California|Monterey]], [[Napa County, California|Napa]], [[San Benito County, California|San Benito]], [[Santa Cruz County, California|Santa Cruz]], [[Tulare County, California|Tulare]] and [[Yolo County, California|Yolo]] counties. Latinos make up at least 20% of the [[San Francisco Bay Area]]. Many live in [[San Mateo County, California|San Mateo]], [[Alameda County, California|Alameda]], [[Contra Costa County, California|Contra Costa]] and [[Santa Clara County, California|Santa Clara]] counties, as well in [[San Francisco]]. The [[Napa Valley]] and [[Salinas Valley]] have predominantly Latino communities established by migrant farm workers. San Jose is about 30-35 percent Latino, the largest Latino community in northern California, while the [[Mission District, San Francisco]] and Lower/[[West Oakland]] has [[barrio]]s established by Mexican and Latin American immigrants. The Mexican American communities of [[East Los Angeles (region)|East Los Angeles]] and [[Logan Heights, San Diego]], as well the [[San Joaquin Valley]] are centers of historic [[Chicano]] and Latino cultures. California also has the largest populations of Hispanics/Latinos in the country. Most of the state's Latinos have [[Mexican people|Mexican]] ancestry, having the largest Mexican population in the United States, making up about 31 percent of the state population. California has a large and diverse population, having the largest [[Central America]]n, especially [[Salvadoran American|Salvadorans]] population in the United States. [[Guatemalan American]]s are spread out in Southern California after previously centered in Los Angeles between 1970 and 2010. California also has many [[Cuban Americans]], [[Puerto Rican American|Puerto Ricans]], [[Honduran American]]s, and [[Nicaraguan American]]s, along with people of [[Brazilian American|Brazilian]], [[Chilean American|Chilean]], [[Colombian American|Colombian]], [[Peruvian American|Peruvian]] and other [[South America]]n ancestry. Los Angeles has had the United States' largest [[Central America]]n community, as well as the largest Mexican American community, since the 1910s. In fact, the 1900 census record finds 319 to 619 out of 100,000 residents in the city of Los Angeles were "Spanish" or "Mexican". (see [[Demographics of Los Angeles]]). Nearly 31 percent of Los Angeles itself is of Mexican descent, having the largest Mexican population of any city in the United States. In [[Mariposa County, California|Mariposa County]], there is a very small community of Californios or Spanish American people as they identify themselves, that dates back before the U.S. annexation of California. [[Hornitos, California|Hornitos]] is home to an estimated 1,000 people and many are "[[Californios]]". The community's "Spanish" Californio culture is closely linked with Mexico and other Latin American nations. Spanish colonial/Mexican/Latino influences was always a major part of California after it became part of the U.S. since 1848 and its statehood in 1850. {{citation needed|date=May 2012}} The state has a long history of established [[Asian American]] communities, including Chinese since the 1850s, Japanese since the 1880s, and Filipinos for over a century. A large wave of Asian immigration since 1965 brought in more Chinese along with Koreans and [[Southeast Asians]] after the Vietnam war ended in the late 1970s. South Asians are also a fast-growing group. As of the [[2010 United States Census|2010 Census]] there were a total of 17,941,286 respondents who claimed to be [[Asian American]] and Asian.{{cite web |url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?pid=DEC_10_SF1_PCT7&prodType=table#tab_map |title=ASIAN ALONE OR IN COMBINATION WITH ONE OR MORE OTHER RACES, AND WITH ONE OR MORE ASIAN CATEGORIES FOR SELECTED GROUPS |author= |work=2010 Census |publisher=U.S. Census Bureau |accessdate=5 January 2012}} Out of these respondents in the United States,{{cite web |url=https://www.census.gov/prod/cen2010/briefs/c2010br-02.pdf |title=Overview of Race and Hispanic Origin: 2010 |author=Karen R. Humes |author2=Nicholas A. Jones |author3=Roberto R. Ramirez |date=March 2011 |work=United States Census Bureau |publisher=U.S. Department of Commerce |accessdate=5 January 2012}} 30.9% live in California, with 5,556,592 Asian Americans being counted by the 2010 Census.{{cite web |url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?pid=DEC_10_SF2_SF2DP1&prodType=table |title=DP-1 Profile of General Population and Housing Characteristics: 2010 (2010 Census Summary File 2) |author= |year=2010 |work=2010 Census |publisher=United States Census Bureau |accessdate=28 January 2013}} This is a 1.5 million growth in population from the 2000 census, making Asian Americans 14.9 percent of the state's population.{{cite news |title=California has by far nation's largest Asian-American population |author=Dan Walters |url=http://blogs.sacbee.com/capitolalertlatest/2012/03/california-has-by-far-nations-largest-asian-american-population.html |newspaper=Sacramento Bee |date=12 March 2012 |accessdate=28 January 2013}} Out of those almost 5.6 million Asian Americans in California there are 1,474,707 [[Filipino American|Filipinos]], 1,349,111 [[Chinese American|Chinese]], 647,589 [[Vietnamese American|Vietnamese]], 590,445 [[Indian American|Indians]], 505,225 [[Korean American|Koreans]], 428,140 [[Japanese American|Japanese]], 109,928 [[Taiwanese American|Taiwanese]], 102,317 [[Cambodian Americans|Cambodians]], 91,224 [[Hmong American|Hmong]], 69,303 [[Laotian American|Laotians]], 67,707 [[Thai American|Thais]], 53,474 [[Pakistani American|Pakistanis]], 39,506 Borneons, Sumatrans, and [[Indonesian American|Indonesians]], 17,978 [[Burmese American|Burmese]], 11,929 [[Sri Lankan American|Sri Lankans]], 10,494 [[Bangladeshi American|Bangladeshis]], 6,231 [[Nepalese American|Nepalese]], 5,595 [[Malaysian American|Malaysians]], 4,993 [[Mongolian American|Mongolians]], 1,513 [[Singaporean American|Singaporeans]], 1,377 [[Okinawan American|Okinawans]], and 750 [[Bhutanese American|Bhutanese]]. Filipino Americans are particularly numerous in [[Los Angeles]], [[Sacramento]], [[San Francisco]], [[San Diego]], [[San Mateo County, California|San Mateo]] and [[Solano County, California|Solano]] counties, and in southern California communities such as [[Artesia, California|Artesia]], [[Baldwin Park, California|Baldwin Park]], [[Carson, California|Carson]], [[Cerritos, California|Cerritos]], [[Covina, California|Covina]], [[West Covina, California|West Covina]], and the [[Eagle Rock, Los Angeles, California|Eagle Rock]] district of Los Angeles. Around San Diego, many Filipinos live in the communities of [[Mira Mesa, California|Mira Mesa]], [[National City, California|National City]], and [[Chula Vista, California|Chula Vista]]. [[Delano, California|Delano]] near Bakersfield, other towns in the [[San Joaquin Valley]], the [[Inland Empire, California|Inland Empire]] of [[Riverside, California|Riverside]]-[[San Bernardino, California|San Bernardino]], [[Coachella Valley]]-[[Imperial Valley]] region, [[Salinas, California|Salinas]], [[Stockton, California|Stockton]] and [[Lathrop, California|Lathrop]], and the [[Santa Maria, California|Santa Maria]]/[[San Luis Obispo]] area also have large Filipino American populations. [[Daly City]] south of [[San Francisco]] has a large Filipino population and is the largest percentage wise in the United States. As of the 1980s, Filipinos have been the largest population of Asians in California.{{cite news |last=Archibold |first=Randal C. |date=20 August 1993 |title=Political Awakening : Filipino-Americans Start to Reach for Reins of Power |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-08-20/local/me-25819_1_filipino-american-community |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=24 November 2014 }} Twenty percent of [[registered nurses]], in 2013, in California are Filipino.{{cite news |title=Telltale Signs: "Why are there so many Filipino nurses in the US?" |author=Rodel Rodis |url=http://www.asianweek.com/2013/05/14/telltale-signs-why-are-there-so-many-filipino-nurses-in-the-us/ |newspaper=Asian Week |date=14 May 2013 |accessdate=19 May 2013}} Chinese Americans are numerous in [[San Francisco]], Oakland, the [[East Bay (San Francisco Bay Area)|East Bay]], [[South Bay (San Jose, California)|South Bay]], the [[Central Coast (California)|Central Coast of California]], [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]], [[San Diego]], and the [[San Gabriel Valley]] region of Los Angeles County. The San Francisco Bay Area has a greater concentration of Cantonese-speaking Chinese than any other region in the United States. The Mexican border community of [[Calexico, California]] in addition to [[Mexicali, Baja California|Mexicali]] has large numbers of Chinese Mexican Americans, that is, Mexican Americans of Chinese ancestry. Smaller Chinese communities can also be found in [[San Jacinto, California|San Jacinto Valley]], [[Lake Elsinore, California|Lake Elsinore]], and [[Victorville, California|Victorville]]. Southern California has perhaps the largest Taiwan-born Chinese American community in the U.S., particularly in the San Gabriel Valley (i.e. [[Walnut, California|Walnut]] and [[Diamond Bar, California|Diamond Bar]]), [[Buena Park, California|Buena Park]], [[Cerritos, California|Cerritos]], [[West Covina, California|West Covina]], [[Irvine, California|Irvine]], communities in the [[South Bay, Los Angeles]] and southern Orange County. Many minority groups from China also live in California, for example, there are [[Tibetan people|Tibetan]], [[Mongols|Mongolian]] and [[Uyghurs|Uyghur]] Americans concentrated in San Francisco, Oakland, San Jose, Orange County, and the Los Angeles/Long Beach area. Large Korean American communities exist in the [[Koreatown, Los Angeles, California|Koreatown]] area of Los Angeles, the eastern [[San Gabriel Valley]], the [[San Fernando Valley]], Cerritos/Long Beach, [[South Bay, Los Angeles]], northern Orange County and [[San Diego]] area. There is another large Korean American population in the San Francisco Bay Area, and Koreans are growing in number in the suburban [[Inland Empire, California|Inland Empire]] region, in cities such as [[Chino Hills, California|Chino Hills]], [[Corona, California|Corona]], [[Desert Hot Springs, California|Desert Hot Springs]] and [[Loma Linda, California|Loma Linda]] south of [[San Bernardino]]. Since 1990, the Korean American and African American populations relocated westward and northward in the Los Angeles area. The [[South Bay, Los Angeles|South Bay]] area and [[Little Tokyo, Los Angeles, California|Little Tokyo]] have a large Japanese American community. Japanese Americans, however, are also concentrated in [[San Francisco]] and across the Bay Area, [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], the [[Salinas Valley]] and [[Santa Cruz County, California|Santa Cruz County]]; and smaller communities in the [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]], [[Fresno, California|Fresno]], [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]], [[Anaheim, California|Anaheim]], [[San Diego]], [[San Bernardino, California|San Bernardino]], [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]] and [[Stockton, California|Stockton]] areas. Despite the presence of Japanese goods stores, media outlets and restaurants in the state, most "Little Tokyos" and "Japantowns" were evacuated during the forced relocation of Japanese Americans during [[World War II]] (see [[Japanese American Internment]]). As a result, most Japanese Americans in urban areas do not reside in historical Japanese communities. California has the largest American population of Southeast Asians, concentrated in the Los Angeles-Long Beach, Sacramento, and Fresno areas. This includes the [[Hmong people|Hmong]] and Vietnamese, including [[Hoa people|Chinese Vietnamese]]. [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]] has one of the largest Cambodian American communities in the United States. The neighboring cities of [[Westminster, California|Westminster]] and [[Garden Grove, California|Garden Grove]] have the largest Vietnamese American community outside of Vietnam and are often dubbed "[[Little Saigon]]". Vietnamese and Cambodian immigrants also settled in the San Francisco Bay Area, especially San Jose, [[Santa Clara, California|Santa Clara]] and [[Sunnyvale, California|Sunnyvale]], as well across the [[San Joaquin Valley]] and in [[San Diego]]. Over 6,000 Laotian Americans live in the [[Fresno, California|Fresno]] area, including an even larger Hmong American community, the second-largest of its kind. Other Hmong colonies in the [[Central Valley of California]] and [[Northern California]] developed since the end of the Vietnam war (1975–79). California also has a Thai American community of over 250,000, concentrated in Southern California, with small Thai and Southeast Asian communities in [[Perris, California|Perris]] and [[Banning, California|Banning]] in the Inland Empire region. Los Angeles has the largest Thai population outside of Thailand and is also home to the world's first [[Thai Town, Los Angeles|Thai Town]]. About 150,000 [[Overseas Indonesian|Indonesians]] live in Southern California, primarily the Los Angeles and San Diego areas. California has the largest Indian American population in the U.S. Many live in the [[Los Angeles Metropolitan Area]], [[San Diego]], and the [[San Francisco Bay Area]]. The Los Angeles suburbs of [[Artesia, California|Artesia]] and [[Cerritos, California|Cerritos]] have large Indian American communities. [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], [[Fremont, California|Fremont]], and other [[Silicon Valley]] cities have many Indian Americans who are employed in the high-tech industry. Many Indian Americans are in [[California Central Valley|Central Valley]] cities such as Stockton, Bakersfield, Fresno, [[Yuba City, California|Yuba City]], and the [[Imperial Valley (California)|Imperial Valley]]. Most South Asians in California are Indian American, but there are also Pakistani Americans, Bangladeshi Americans, and Sri Lankan Americans (see [[Sinhalese people|Sinhalese]] and [[Tamil people|Tamil]]s) esp. concentrated in the San Gabriel Valley ([[Covina, California|Covina Valley]]) of the Los Angeles area. Over 50,000 [[Afghan American]]s are concentrated in the [[East Bay (San Francisco Bay Area)|East Bay]] primarily in [[Alameda County, California|Alameda County]] and its communities of [[Fremont, California|Fremont]] and [[Hayward, California|Hayward]]; Afghans also live throughout the state (esp. Orange County and [[Ventura County, California|Ventura County]]). The state has 150,000 residents with [[Pacific Islander American|Pacific Islander]] ancestry. Most, 80,000, are [[Native Hawaiian]]s of measurable Polynesian ancestry; many also have Asian, European, or other ancestries. There are also 25,000 [[Samoan American]]s originally from [[American Samoa]] or [[Western Samoa]]. Most live in [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]] and the Los Angeles suburbs of [[Carson, California|Carson]], Artesia, Cerritos, and [[Redondo Beach, California|Redondo Beach]], [[Oceanside, California|Oceanside]], and [[Upland, California|Upland]]. About 10,000 [[Chamorros]] from [[Guam]] and [[Northern Mariana Islands]] live in northern California, the largest Micronesian community in the mainland United States. An estimated 10,000 [[Tahiti]]ans from [[French Polynesia]] live in southern California. {{citations needed|date=March 2018}} There are also many [[Palauan American|Palau]]ans in southern California, specifically in the San Diego area, including [[Vista, California|Vista]]. Only 677 in Vista alone in the 2010 US Census. Members of the [[Palauan]] community often also have [[Malaysia|Malay]], [[Indonesia]]n, [[Micronesia]]n, [[Melanesian]], [[Japanese people|Japanese]], and other east Asian ancestries. Many Chuukese or [[Chuuk State|Trukese]] live in San Diego, while the original settlers on [[Chuuk State|Truk Island]] are [[Spanish people|Spanish]] and [[Germans|German]] but most Truukese now are Japanese and Korean, then Filipino and some Chinese, and finally the arrival of American expatriates. Many came to the [[Oceanside, California|Oceanside]] area due to the military installations around the city, which has the oldest [[Polynesians|Polynesian]] or Pacific Islander community. The state also has over 715,000 [[Arab American]]s, with large communities in Alameda, Fresno, Imperial, Kern, Orange, San Bernardino, San Diego, [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]] and [[Stanislaus County|Stanislaus]] counties. They represent all Arab and Middle Eastern nationalities, the most numerous being of [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]] and [[West Bank]] (see [[Palestinian American]]s) followed by those from [[Syria]] (see [[Syrian American]]s) and [[Lebanon]] (about half- 1.5 out of 3.1 million estimated- (see [[Lebanese American]]s) live in California), [[Algeria]], [[Bahrain]], [[Egypt]], [[Iraq]], [[Jordan]], [[Kuwait]], [[Libya]], [[Morocco]], [[Oman]], [[Qatar]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Tunisia]], [[United Arab Emirates]] and [[Yemen]]. Arabs have resided in California since the 1920s, most notably in [[Orange County, California|Orange County]] in the section of [[Little Arabia (Anaheim, California)]] and the [[San Diego, California|San Diego]] area. About 500,000 [[Iranian American]]s live throughout [[Southern California]], including about 20% of the population of [[Beverly Hills, California|Beverly Hills]].{{Cite web| url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5459468 | title=Living in Tehrangeles: L.A.'s Iranian Community | first=Renee | last=Montagne|publisher=[[National Public Radio]] | date=2006-06-08|accessdate=2006-06-28}} Iranian American communities also flourish in the [[San Fernando Valley]], Orange County, San Diego, the Palm Springs area, and the San Joaquin Valley. The majority of [[Iranian American]]s immigrated after the ouster of the pro-U.S. Shah regime of Iran in the late 1970s. California also has the third largest [[Greek American]] population in the United States, behind [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[Massachusetts]]. There is also large population of [[Assyrian/Chaldean/Syriac people|Assyrian/Chaldean]] descent living in the Central Valley, with large communities in [[Modesto, California|Modesto]], [[Ceres, California|Ceres]] and [[Turlock, California|Turlock]], as well as throughout the Central Coast and the California Desert (i.e. the [[Coachella Valley|Coachella]] and [[Imperial Valley (California)|Imperial]] valleys). San Diego has one of the largest concentrations of [[Chaldean people|Chaldean]] immigrants in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://chaldeanchamber.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=12&Itemid=35|title=Chaldean Chamber of Commerce|website=chaldeanchamber.com|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} California is also home to 600,000 [[Armenian Americans]], with many in [[Glendale, California|Glendale]] north of Los Angeles, as well as a large community in [[Fresno, California|Fresno]]. As of 1988 California had about 500,000 ethnic Armenians with over half of them living in [[Greater Los Angeles Area|Greater Los Angeles]]."[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=LA&p_theme=la&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EF5191E679C4A7D&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM ARMENIAN PONTIFF BEGINS VISIT TO SOUTHLAND WITH ENCINO STOP]." ''[[Los Angeles Daily News]]''. June 17, 1988. Article ID 8801240266. "About 500000 Armenians live in California - more than half of them in the Los Angeles area." [[Turkish Americans]] and [[Azerbaijani Americans]] form moderately-sized communities in both [[Los Angeles]] and [[San Francisco]]. California has 2.3 million African Americans as of 2010, the largest population of Black or African Americans in the western U.S, and the 5th largest Black population in the United States. Cities that have the largest share of African Americans and have historically been Black cultural centers include (11 largest in the state): [[Compton, California|Compton]], [[Inglewood, California|Inglewood]], [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]], [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[Richmond, California|Richmond]], [[Riverside, California|Riverside]], [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]], [[San Bernardino, California|San Bernardino]], [[San Diego, California|San Diego]] and [[Vallejo, California|Vallejo]]. There are many other cities and towns in the state with sizeable African American populations. These include: [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]], [[Dublin, California|Dublin]], [[East Palo Alto, California|East Palo Alto]], [[Fairfield, California|Fairfield]], [[Hayward, California|Hayward]], [[Marin City, California|Marin City]], [[Piedmont, California|Piedmont]], [[San Leandro, California|San Leandro]], and [[Suisun City, California|Suisun City]]. [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]], [[Fresno, California|Fresno]], [[Merced, California|Merced]], [[Modesto, California|Modesto]], and [[Stockton, California|Stockton]]. [[Adelanto, California|Adelanto]], [[Altadena, California|Altadena]], [[Apple Valley, California|Apple Valley]], [[California City, California|California City]], [[Carson, California|Carson]], [[Corona, California|Corona]], [[Desert Hot Springs, California|Desert Hot Springs]], [[Fontana, California|Fontana]], [[Gardena, California|Gardena]], [[Hawthorne, California|Hawthorne]], [[Indio, California|Indio]], [[Lakewood, California|Lakewood]], [[Lancaster, California|Lancaster]], [[Lynwood, California|Lynwood]], [[Moreno Valley, California|Moreno Valley]], [[National City, California|National City]], [[Oceanside, California|Oceanside]], [[Palmdale, California|Palmdale]], [[Palm Springs, California|Palm Springs]], [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]], [[Perris, California|Perris]], [[Pomona, California|Pomona]], [[Rialto, California|Rialto]], [[Twentynine Palms, California|Twentynine Palms]], and [[Victorville, California|Victorville]]. African Americans are approximately 7 percent of the state population. The state percentage of African Americans has dropped in the 1990s and 2000s, though the state's overall ''number'' of African-Americans has increased in that time period. The black population in East and West Oakland and South Central Los Angeles - places where they held the majority for decades - has greatly decreased as the black middle class has relocated to nearby suburbs, including those in the [[Inland Empire]] and [[Antelope Valley]] in Southern California and the [[Sacramento metropolitan area]] in Northern California. Many African Americans have also moved to the [[Southeastern United States|South]], where their grandparents may have come from in the "[[Great Migration (African American)|Great Migration]]" of the mid-20th century. African Americans have made a contribution to the state's hip-hop and R&B music culture. African-American musical artists born and/or raised in California include: [[Snoop Dogg]], [[Dr. Dre]], [[Ice Cube]], [[E-40]], [[Nate Dogg]], [[En Vogue]], [[Tony! Toni! Tone!]], [[Too Short]], [[Eazy-E]], [[N.W.A]], [[Keyshia Cole]], [[Digital Underground]], [[JJ Fad]], [[Barry White]], [[The Pointer Sisters]] and [[Kendrick Lamar]]. Also noted is California has small [[West Indian]] ([[Afro-Caribbean American]]) and African immigration from countries such as [[Cape Verde]], [[Eritrea]] and [[Ethiopia]] (i.e. [[Little Ethiopia]] in [[West Los Angeles]]), [[Ghana]], [[Kenya]], [[Nigeria]], [[Senegal]], [[Somalia]], [[South Africa]] (including [[White South Africans]]), [[Tanzania]] and [[Yemen]] across from the Horn of Africa. They established communities in [[Los Angeles]] known for a large Ethiopian community and [[Oakland]]/[[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]] (East Bay) as well [[Nuer people|Nuer]] refugees from [[South Sudan]] migrated to the [[Sacramento]] area; and the [[Cape Verde]]an community in [[Solano County, California|Solano County]] and the [[Santa Clara Valley]], and the [[San Diego]] area. As of 2010, California's Native American population of 362,801 was the most of any state.{{cite web| url=http://blogs.sacbee.com/capitolalertlatest/2013/12/california-has-nations-largest-native-american-population.html |author= Capitol Alert |publisher=Sacramento Bee |title=Capitol Alert: California has nation's largest Native American population | date= Dec 23, 2013| accessdate=February 4, 2015}} It also has the [[List of federally recognized tribes by state#California|most Native American tribes]], indigenous to the state or not, but the majority of known [[Native Americans in the United States|Californian Indian]] tribes became extinct in the late 19th century. The U.S. Census includes ''Latin American Indian'', especially immigrants who belonged to indigenous peoples or who have Amerindian heritage from North and South America. The [[Cherokee Nation]] is the largest tribe in the state with a population of 110,000, although the number of Cherokee descendants may surpass 600,000 according to demographers. They are often descendants of [[Dust Bowl]] refugees in the 1930s and 1940s who migrated to the state's farming counties and urban areas for jobs. The largest urban American Indian communities are Los Angeles/Long Beach, San Francisco/Oakland, Sacramento, and San Diego areas. {{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} California also has significant populations of the [[Apache]], [[Choctaw]], [[Creek people|Creek]], [[Hopi]], [[Zuni people|Zuni]], [[Navajo people|Navajo]], [[Blackfoot Confederacy|Blackfeet]], [[Shoshone]], [[Northern Paiute|Paiute]], [[Pueblo Indians|Pueblos]], [[Cahuilla people|Cahuilla]] and [[Chumash (tribe)|Chumash]] tribes. The Cahuilla in the Coachella Valley have profited from real estate land leases, and much of [[Indio, California|Indio]] and [[Palm Springs, California|Palm Springs]] are tribal-owned lands under legal tribal jurisdiction.{{cite web|url=http://archive.desertsun.com/article/20131012/NEWS01/310120044/New-tribal-land-tax-law-causing-alarm-Palm-Springs |last=Newkirk |first=Barrett |title=New
